body.p:
I have duly
received yours of the 19th February, & I hope
you will excuse me for not writing to you
ere this, as I have been continually closely
occupied for the last few months.

In the 20th of April, I have sent you by letter to Mr. M. Roggenburger a Dft. Of 33—,
which I trust you have recd in the full en-
joyment of health.

I send you enclosed a statement of
your a/c, which exhibits Balance of 13.42 on
hand, which I shall endeavor to swell to
a larger amt., & then I'll remit. In the said
statement you will perceive what is for the
“Occident” & acknowledge the same as usual
in the “Occ.” I have settled with Haas
& Rosenfeld for $97 to be in full & they
desire a discontinuance of the subscription
of the O. that in the best I could effect
with them. Mr. S. R. Rosenthal also wishes
to discontinue the “Occid.,” & promised to pay
son his subscription dues. Mr. Dessau has
left the state with his family, & I do not see
any chance how you will ever receive
one Cent from him. I hope you have

stopped long since to send him the “Occid.”
Mr. S. I. Meyer & Co have only paid $6.00, as
you'll perceive, as they say it were possible
Mr. A. Jacobs their partner, residing in New
York may have paid their subscription dues
therefore please let me know in relation
to it. You will otherwise notice, that
collections are made very slowly; people
here do not like to pay. & in reference
to getting subscriptions to the contemplated
translations, I have been unsuccessful.

Dr. Eckman has requested me to
ask you the amt. Of his dues to the Occi-
dent; wishing to pay the same.

The President of the Congregation
“Emanu-El” has also desired me to
inform you to send the Bill for the adver-
tisement of the ministry of this congregation
for payment.

I am truly sorry, that you find
cause of so much complaint against your
the course of your religious opponents. Though
to advise you would for me be out of
place, yet as a true friend I take the
liberty to remark, that whilst I do deeply
sympathize with your arduous duties in battling
against such a bitter opposition, & whilst your
course is applauded still by a large multi-
tude, it being a noble & honorable one,

I regret very much that the writings should
trouble you so much. You should remember,
that the mass of the people are capable
of judging between right & wrong, & there-
fore your severe opponents cannot hurt
you. As a journalist you must expect
such attacks, & your success in meeting
them reflects upon your credit & honor.

I have with much gratification learned
that you are being elected as minister of
a new Portuguese congregation in Phil.;
allow me to extend my congratulations, &
my sincere wishes for true success.

The news relating to Jewish affairs are
very dull & scarce. The congregation
Emanu-El, are now without any
minister; they are anxiously awaiting
a response of some suitable person to their advertisements. An able man can
here find a good post, & can find a
wide field for doing good. The congre-
gation at their last meeting have changed
the resolution effecting the election of
a minister, so that $3000— salary annually
is paid for 2 years &c. I understand
that you have officially been informed of this
change, & that an advertisement to that effect
had been ordered. Mr. D. Levy is now
the teacher of the Hebrew School attached

to & supported by the congregation E-El, who in
connection with the Heb. Department has established
a regular school for the instruction of all other
& secular branches. This school is well & ably
conducted, & the pupils have made great pro-
gress within the short time since; the school
is under the direction of D. Levy Esq.

At the meeting of the congregation
“Bnai Israel” Sacramento, April 12th the following
officers were elected for the ensuing
year: Geo. Aaronson Pres. A. Mayer
Vice. Pres., J. S. Winehill Sec.
M. S. Myers Treasu. L. Godstein,
I. Rosenheim & L. Shawl Trustees
A. Gallard Chazan & Shochet.

Owing to some difficulty originating
from the desire of the minority of members
to establish a Heb. School to be supported
by the congregation, a succession of those
members, composing the minority has
taken place, who have recently organized
a distinct congregation, and have
elected the following gent. for their officers:
Louis Sloss, Pres., L. Lehman Vice
Pres., I. Eppinger Sec. L. Bucki Treas.
L. Godshaw, S. Hoffman & H. Davis Trust.
This congregation has established a religious
school, in connection with & have elected
Mr. Borris as the teacher & shochet.
